figure_1.caption: Representation of the development of the topic tool used for coding chiropractic education publications included in this review

figure_2.title: Figure 2.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Distribution of the primary chiropractic education-related topics published between 1970 and 2023

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption:
The number of study designs in the included chiropractic education publications over time (1970–2023), in 5-year increments
Note that the last time block (2020 through November 6, 2023) represents 4 years.

claims.sentence: The codes for programs were included in the topic tool to accommodate publications that address information about education and delivery of chiropractic training (see Figure 1).

After the full-text screening, 598 papers remained for data extraction (see Figure 2).27


Figure 2.
Figure 3 shows the countries where chiropractic education was researched.

Twenty sources were identified as “other” or “unspecified.”


Figure 3.

Not shown in figure: Europe (n=11) and other non-specified (n=20). (Map created via Microsoft Excel)Ten journals published the majority (86%) of the publications that focused on chiropractic (Figure 4).
The proportion of study designs over time is shown in Figure 5.

The number of study designs in the included chiropractic education publications over time (1970–2023), in 5-year increments
Note that the last time block (2020 through November 6, 2023) represents 4 years.Figure 6 reveals the topics with the greatest and least number of publications within each topic area.
Figure 7 shows the changes in the number of published studies over time based on their primary topics.
